Speaker: story by
Dialogue: Peter Viertel

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: Wait a minute -- stop --

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: All right --  What are you girls doin' way out here?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Until you came along we were going to Sonora.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: What do you know about that. Did you sell your place?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Can I make it?

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: Depends on how good you drive.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: She's a little out of practice.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: Slide over.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm slidin' all the way over.

Speaker: marcia
Dialogue: So am I. Come on Elaine.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: What's the difference if we fall in the canyon.

Speaker: marcia
Dialogue: Don't talk like that.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: Nothin' to it --

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: -- once you know how. Trouble is, never was a woman knew how to handle a team. Shouldn't let 'em loose on the roads. No disrespect meant, Miss Wells.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: Get up.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: There you are. Now take it easy and you'll be all right.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr. Graham.

Speaker: marcia
Dialogue: There's -- dead men -- in your wagon!

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: That's right. You had me so busy I forgot --  Come to think of it you better turn around and drive right back to Aspen.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: They were murdered. I found the bodies on Alder Crick, northeast of here. Like I said if I was you, I'd go back, because the men who killed them might be on this road.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Back to what?

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: Why, back to Aspen, where you came from.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Aspen doesn't want us Mr. Graham. They threw us out.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: They shouldn't have done that.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We tried to point that out. But there were some pretty nosey citizens who wouldn't listen to reason. They said Aspen had outgrown us. It's all right to play poker in your own home but not in a saloon.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: I knew something would happen when they started puttin' up fences and passin' laws.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Goodbye and thanks.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: I don't like to see you go.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: But that's the way it is. The live ones go out and the dead ones come in.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: How does she draw?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: A little hot.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You want to get out of here before noon, maybe you should lend me a hand.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Rate you're goin', we'll be here until winter.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Account of you, I miss out on the only excitement Aspen's had for months.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You're too old to watch such goin's on.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: And I'm too young.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I don't see no sense to makin' people leave town if they don't want to leave.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I don't either -- when people are that good-lookin'. Maybe that's why -- they were too good-lookin'.  But there'll be others along to take their place after a while when this quiets down. And everything will be fine until some busybody starts stirring up trouble.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Don't you ever run down?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Some people just have to run other people's lives. Now take Clay. You want to amble up the street and see the fun and what does he say?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You stick to your blacksmithin' and let me take care of Steve.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: We'll both take a look. Anything's better than listenin' to Sam.  Don't forget to shoe the mule.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Who are they?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Don't know. Graham brought 'em in.

Speaker: gardner's voice
Dialogue: Clay, come up here a minute.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Hello Graham -- Joe -- Mr. Gardner.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: Graham's got something to tell you might interest you.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: Cal Forster and his sons. Somebody killed 'em.

Speaker: graham
Dialogue: You know that cottonwood grove on Alder Crick? They must have been eatin' breakfast the way it looked, sittin' by the fire eatin' breakfast and when I got there nothin' but them lyin' dead in their underdrawers. No horses or guns or grub.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: But what's that got to do with me? I came into town from the south.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: This was smoulderin' on the fire.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I still don't see.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: I got it day before yesterday.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: Now are you interested?

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: You should be. Maybe Lednov heard about that Sonora ranch of yours.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Maybe he did.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: We're going to look for him. Want to come along?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I've got eleven horses to get over the mountains before snow catches me and covers the feed.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: And that's more important than finding Lednov?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Like you said, maybe he knows where my ranch is. If he does, he'll be waiting on the porch.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: I'll drop the sheriff in Sonora a line to sort of look around for him.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Who's Lednov?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: A man I used to know.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Forget somethin', Clay?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Shells. How much for six boxes?

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Six times six bits. But wait until I finish this.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You might tell a fellow things, 'specially if the fellow's your brother, seems to me.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Like why you're buyin' a whole slew of 30 30 shells all of a sudden.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I don't want to run short.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You never said this Lednov's name before, that I can remember.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: No call to. That jail looked pretty solid to me.  How's she feel?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Nice.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: You know bettern' to do that, Steve. Unless you're figurin' on buyin' it.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: One he's got, more his size.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: But it's leaded up and anyway a 22's no good for real huntin'. You shoot a man with a 22 and where are you?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: The thing to do is stick to rabbits.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: What was he in jail for?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You sure worry that bone. He killed a fellow.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: In a fight?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: The other fellow wasn't even lookin'.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: This is an awful nice gun.  Certainly come in handy when there's men around who shoot people that aren't lookin'.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I may as well buy it for him. Otherwise he'll be crying all the way over the hill.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You must be plenty worried about Lednov sneakin' up on us.  Think he will?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: At the ranch maybe?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Maybe at the ranch. Maybe sooner than that.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Do you have to be so close-mouthed? I'm your brother. And I'm ridin' with you. Remember?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: All right. I'll tell you.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Let's say this is the penitentiary.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Here's Alder Crick.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: And here we are in Aspen.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's Sonora.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: motioning) Lednov gets out of jail and comes along here to Alder Crick. Then goes along here toward the Sonora road.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's Lednov!  We come along here.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: And meet him there.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Unless the sheriff gets too close and he holes up.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: So let's go.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Sure a lot of guys lookin' for Lednov.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Yeah -- and Lednov's only lookin' for one man. Me.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: He doesn't like me. What you eatin'?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Lednov.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I don't like him.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Another one, Clay.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: They sure must have been travelin'. This keeps up we can start a store.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Things get tough next winter, you'll have somethin' to wear.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'd look good doin' the ploughin' in this.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Anybody hurt?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No. We came down the hill a little fast and...  Can you fix it for us?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What's the matter with her?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Too much excitement. How about the surrey. Can you fix it?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Jimininy. You sure were lucky, just bustin' a wheel.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You think that'sall we busted -- You should see...

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: This must have been in the family a long time.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It was a gift from the citizens of Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And this is Helen Carter.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm Clay Phillips.  My brother Steve.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: We found your trunk. Were you doin' the driven'?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I was at first. Then I was hanging on.  Are you going far?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: As far as -- Sonora?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Just about.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We're going to Sonora, too, so that solves everything.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We can ride in your wagon.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We wouldn't think of asking you to take us for nothing.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: There's only four of us.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I've got eleven horses.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Morgan blood. The beat in Nevada. Clay and me have a place on the Toulomne River. We're going to raise horses like these.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: They won't be riding in the wagon.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Did you ever try taking a bunch of horses over Sonora Pass? It's quite a job.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You can't leave us here.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Course I can't. I'll give you a lift to the first ranch.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What good is it going to do us to go to some ranch?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You can stay here if you like.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We have to get to Sonora. There are jobs waiting for us there. We'll pay you for your trouble.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm not running a stage line, ma'am, and I can't take a chance on losing the horses.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: When you're old enough to smoke, I'll tell you.  Get the horses started on ahead, will you, Steve?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Afraid it will stop him growin'?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Let's get your stuff in the wagon. Like I said, I'll take you to the first ranch. I wish I could carry you all the way, but I can't. It's a tough trip and women would be in the way.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Our kind of women?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You'll have to drive -- except down hill.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Maybe you're going about this all wrong. Why not try telling him we'll do the cookin' and mendin' and washin' for him. That usually works.  Yeah, but suppose he took us up on it. Where would we be?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Maybe in Sonora.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What's the matter with her?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Too much excitement. Or maybe it's just the heat. How about the surrey. Can you fix it?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Jiminy. You sure were lucky, just bustin' a wheel.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You think that's all we busted -- You should see...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Now where's she goin'? --

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I -- lost something.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: It wouldn't happen to be this...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Who's the old folks?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Give it to me!

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: This must have been in the family a long time.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It was a gift from the citizens of Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And this is Helen Carter.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm Clay Phillips.  My brother Steve.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: We found your trunk. Were you doin' the drivin'?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Come on, Honeybunch. We're changing trains.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: A nice, kind wrangler is letting us ride in his wagon...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: ...as far as the first ranch. From then on --

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: What ranch?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What's the difference?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Ask him what ranch --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: There's plenty of time for that.  Come on, now. You've got to lie down out of this sun. Stop worrying. I'll find out what ranch after a while.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Stretch out under the seat, Miss.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Which ranch?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: She's worried about where you're taking us.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: So am I.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: It's a nice place owned by an old couple named Wyatt.

Speaker: clay's voice
Dialogue: They'll take you in until you can make other arrangements.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: So both of you stop worrying.

Speaker: clay's voice
Dialogue: Steve, see the horses don't drink too much --

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Leave that unharnessing for me, Ma'am.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: There's a place down a ways, where you and the girls can wash some of that dust off.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Thanks. And isn't there something we can do about supper -- or making the beds?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Steve and me, we use a saddle for a pillow and roll up in a tarp.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But you eat, don't you?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Mostly, we open a can of beans and boil some coffee.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Where do you keep the can opener?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: In the grub box.  Toward morning the dew gets kind of heavy so maybe you better fix up a bed under the wagon. Spread some bunch grass under the tarp and the ground won't be so hard.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Marcia -- all of you. Come on.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Where'd they go?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Swimming.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It's sort of nice having company along. Not so lonesome.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: When you get the team watered, rustle up some wood.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You boys have had enough.

Speaker: helen's voice
Dialogue: And I'm the girl who used to complain to my mother about helping with the wash.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Get your rifle.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Hold it.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Drop your gun.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: Drop yours. I'm gunshy.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Then don't come sneakin' around a man's camp.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: A fellow sees a fire go out all of a sudden, he don't take chances. My name's Clayton and I'm looking for someone.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: I found their surrey --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: So did I. They were in it.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: She's a friend -- took off this morning sort of sudden while I wasn't around.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: My brother, Steve. I'm Phillips.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I gave the girls a lift. Didn't know what else to do with them. Get your horse and come on.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Here's a man says he's looking for you girls.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: Hello, Miss Wells.

Speaker: marcia
Dialogue: Jim.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: I was roundin' up some stock. That's why I didn't come sooner.

Speaker: clayton
Dialogue: What do you mean running off without a word.

Speaker: marcia's voice
Dialogue: I didn't know who to tell, it all happened so sudden, those people comin' and throwin' us out on the street.

Speaker: jim's voice
Dialogue: Don't you think about it, darlin'. Don't you think about anythin' but us.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Looks like we lose a good piano player.

Speaker: marcia
Dialogue: Jim came after me, Mary.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I see he did.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: With a milk pail in one hand and a marriage license in the other.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Why didn't you say you wanted to get married back in Aspen. I told the man in Sonora there were four of us. If only three show up, he might call the whole deal off. We've got to stick together. Like we've always done.

Speaker: marcia
Dialogue: I've got a chance to get married.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's what I'm gettin' at. It never works. Don't forget we were thrown out of Aspen.

Speaker: marcia
Dialogue: Jim doesn't care, do you, Jim?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But Jim isn't the only one you're marrying. He has folks and friends. What are they going to say? And how're they going to feel? I tell you, it won't work.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Of course it'll work. You can get another girl to fill out the act.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And look at it this way. How about Jim -- it puts him in a sort of tough spot.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I know what I'm doing. My folks got nothin' to do with it --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You've talked this over with them?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: They know about Marcia.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And they don't like the idea!

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Suppose they don't. This is his problem. He's over twenty-one. He wants to marry Marcia and Marcia wants to marry him so let 'em alone.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: If you were in his shoes would you take one of us home?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm not in his shoes, so leave me out of it.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I would!

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Steve maybe you better get some wood for the fire.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Would you, Mr. Phillips?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Go on, there's a good boy.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't you want him to hear your answer? Well, I know what it is. For the other fellow it's all right -- but not you. All you want is to get rid of one of us.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Wait a minute.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No need of you two arguin' about this. We know what we want to do, and nothin' either of you says makes any difference. We want to go home -- tonight.  Will you sell me one of your horses?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I can't do that. I went a long way to get those horses.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: All right, we'll ride double. Come on, Marcia.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No need to do that, Marcia.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We've got two horses and they're four of us. So half of one of 'em is yours.  The other half's a wedding present.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Big-hearted fella. Can't see young love thwarted -- especially if it makes one less girl to worry about. That's all you really want, isn't it.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Is that your kind of reading, Steve?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I can't read, Ma'am. I just look at the pictures.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You can't read?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Your brother's always looked after you, hasn't he?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Since I can remember, Ma'am.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But he just never troubled to have you get any schooling?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It wasn't Clay's fault. We've been moving around most all the time -- mebbe when we get the ranch and stay in one place I can learn my letters then --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't you even know your letters?

Speaker: steve's voice
Dialogue: No, Ma'am.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Would you like to learn them?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I sure would.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Maybe I could start you out.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: That'd be swell.  You know, you're an awful lot different than I thought you'd be.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You're so nice.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Did someone say I wasn't nice?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Oh no. Nobody said nothing to me. Only I got the idea that -- well Clay and me used to be walking through town and there was your place and through the window I could see you dancing, but Clay always took me over to the other side of the street.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Time to go to bed, Steve.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Good night, Miss Wells.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Good night, Steve.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: There's a nice boy.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That why you always took him on the other side of the street?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Maybe I don't make the grade in some ways, but I know enough to teach a kid his letters.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: He doesn't know his letters, no -- but he knows the names of animals... he knows what roots to eat when you're clear out of food... He knows the difference between a possum and a coon just by lookin' at the tracks... more than most trappers know... and he can tell whether she'll rain or shine tomorrow by smelling the air tonight. There's a lot of things he doesn't know, I hope he'll never learn.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Like sticking his nose into other people's business.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Where's Elaine?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: She was here a while ago.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Elaine!

Speaker: mary's voice
Dialogue: Elaine.  Clay -- Elaine's gone.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: She can't have gone far. I wasn't asleep long.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What would she run off for?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Because she's sick.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Stay here. One woman wanderin' off's enough.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Don't you worry, Miss Wells. We'll find her.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Build the fire up and stick close to it. Come on, Steve.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Look around. She can't have gone far.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Elaine -- Elaine -- Elaine.

Speaker: mary's voice
Dialogue: Elaine -- Elaine.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Ma'am -- you shouldn't have run off like that. Why I was just about to give up lookin'. Come on, now.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You can't stay here. There's snakes and it's cold and you'll just get sicker.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I don't care.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Suppose that Lednov was to have found you, instead of me. Why you wouldn't have had a chance.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I said I didn't care.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: What's botherin' you, anyway?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Runnin' off and worryin' people. Makin' it tougher on Clay than it is already.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Don't ask me because I won't tell you! I won't tell anybody! Go away!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Don't act so -- crazy.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Let's go.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: That's a good girl.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: That's it. Watch out where you're steppin' --

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: That oughta be --  Down.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Lednov --

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: Want to take her off our hands?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Who shot who?

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: Nobody. The light was bad.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: Steve's!

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: What's she doin' runnin' around the country at night.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I wouldn't know. Did you ask her?

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: All I can get out of her is she don't care about livin'.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Look of things, she doesn't.

Speaker: gardner
Dialogue: Yeah. Keep a closer eye on her --  And him. Shootin' going on, we'll never find Lednov.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: There was only three of them at first. I guess I lost my head.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: How'd you happen to miss?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: They were quite a ways off and the wind was blowin'. I didn't have them to aim.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Good thing you didn't.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Clay --

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: A man can't help gettin' excited once in a while.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's right, Steve.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Can I have my gun back?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Sure. You'll find it under the wagon seat. Like I said before, a twenty- two's more your size.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Gee, I can't.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Why not? You went farther than that last time.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'm too old for it, Miss Wells... That's for little kids.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't be silly... Nobody's too old to learn.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Okay. A-B-C -- D-E-F -- G-H-I --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Oh, Steve!

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Get back to the horses. They're straggling.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He's learning his letters.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Yeah. While the horses wander all over the country.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Do like I said.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Learnin' to read has nothing to do with the right or the wrong side of the street.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Are the horses stragglin' or aren't they?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: They're stragglin'.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: His letters will keep.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Steve -- I want you to learn to read. I meant to teach you but I never seemed to find time. I figured when we got settled on the ranch we'd get around to it.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: It's all right with me if she teaches you, but I don't want you forgettin' your job.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I won't again.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: This isn't like other trips we've taken. For one thing, we've got a wagonload of women. For another there's a guy wanderin' around hopin' to put a bullet in my back.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Okeh, I was wrong. But you can't expect a fellow who never saw Lednov and never heard his name until a while ago to do too much worryin'. You've been sorta close mouthed about him.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I guess I have. You were pretty little when they locked him up. I don't suppose you even remember that time I was gone two months.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Sure I remember. You went to Mexico lookin' for cattle.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You remember Jeff Rawson? -- We used to go fishing and hunting with him when you were so high.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Sure I do. Went off down to Mexico or something...

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's what I told you then. Only he didn't. Lednov killed him.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Oh... that's the time you went away.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I caught up with Lednov in Nogales. He didn't like the idea of comin' back across the border but he came. I turned him over to the sheriff and -- that's the story.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Maybe you shoulda killed him.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Maybe I should. But I was never much on killin'. Anyway, he moved too quick and I just got him through the shoulder.  Looks pretty peaceful up ahead.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Yeah, it does.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: But you never can tell. Why don't you get that new rifle out of the wagon?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: And while you're there you might as well find out what comes after K.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Elaine -- stop it --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: She should be in bed where it's dry.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Yes, Ma'am, she should...

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: But the nearest shelter's the Wyatt ranch and that's maybe five hours away.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Can we get a doctor at that ranch?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: No, Ma'am, we can't. We can get a roof and a fire and maybe Mrs. Wyatt knows something about taking care of sick people.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: My name's Wyatt. Certainly glad you boys dropped in.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Those the only horses you got?

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Why, yes. They're all I need...

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Mine's gone lame. Take a look at him.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Go on, we haven't got all day.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Whoa, boy. Let's have a look.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: He dropped a shoe. You shouldn't be ridin' him.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Put on another one.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: That won't help the stone bruise. You ain't been around horses much, looks like.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Will you quit gabbin' and do what you're told.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: All right, but it won't do much good.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: All we want's supper.

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: We're in a hurry.

Speaker: peters
Dialogue: Take care of that horse?

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Yeah. The best I could.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: What are you doin' --

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Lookin' around.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: These all the shells you got?

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Put my guns down and get out of here --

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Your old woman's got sense -- you listen to her.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: I asked you -- these all the shells you got?

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: And hurry that grub up.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Only a little ways now -- maybe a mile.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: How's she makin' out?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: If she feels worse than I do, she's dyin'.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Steve --

Speaker: steve's voice
Dialogue: Yo --

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: I'll have some more of that coffee.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: We got to get movin'.

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Because there's a man I want to see.

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: He can wait. Let's stay here until morning.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: I said let's go.

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: One night more won't matter. Your friend'll be there. Anyway I don't think so much of the idea of prowling around his ranch. He knows you're out so he ain't going to sit still for it.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: I said I had a guy to see and I'm going to see him.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: He gave me something once so I wouldn't forget.

Speaker: peters
Dialogue: He says go, we go.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: If they'd only left me a gun, I'd fix 'em.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Mr. Wyatt.

Speaker: wyatt's voice
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Clay Phillips.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: I'm sure glad it's you. We were afraid those killers might come back.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Three men on matched roans?

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Yeah, how did you know?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: The whole state's lookin' for 'em.  And they're lookin' for me.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Maybe you won't feel that way after I tell you what I stopped in for.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I picked up some women on the road.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: But I'm going to have to leave 'em here. They're --- well they're not the sort of people you're used to.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: And one of 'em is sick.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Put it back.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: It stays there, understand!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Is she very sick?

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Get 'em out of here. I won't have 'em in this house.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: So that was why she tried to run away.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Didn't you know she had a father and mother out here?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I didn't know anything about her except she wanted a job because some man had left her stranded. I couldn't leave her in the street. Let's go.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Hold on.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We can't stay here!

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: It's a long walk back to Aspen.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I don't know about you. But I'm not being thrown out on an empty stomach.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm sorry about this, Mr. Wyatt. I didn't know who she was.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: All right, you didn't know.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I can't take her with me.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Nobody asked you to.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Just get those two out of here.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You're not bein' quite fair.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: What's there to be fair about?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm sorry about this, Mr. Wyatt. I didn't know you had a daughter.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: All right, you didn't know.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I can't take her with me.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Nobody asked you to.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: Just get these two out of here.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You're not bein' quite fair.

Speaker: wyatt
Dialogue: What's there to be fair about?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Wyatt.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Where do I put your things?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Back in the wagon.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Aren't we stayin'?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No. We're not stayin' --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Everything's all mixed up, so don't ask questions.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Go on, Steve.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Sit down and eat, why don't you?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: It isn't like this was the first place we were ever thrown out of.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's not what's worryin' me. Why didn't she tell us? Maybe we could have done somethin' -- gone somewhere else -- puttin' a poor sick kid through this --

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Quit worryin' about Elaine.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: She's home, isn't she? So worry about us. We want to get to Sonora.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: This will be your room until Mr. Wyatt finds time to take you to the nearest stage station.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: That sounds like him.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: This time don't talk about cooking!

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Coffee?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No, thanks.  I hope we won't be a burden to them.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I hope so, too.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: If you're figuring on asking me to take you, it's no use.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: A time like this people ought to be alone. Having us around is going to make it sort of hard on 'em.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm sorry, but that's how it's got to be.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I suppose it is.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: And it's not only because the trip's a tough one --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You don't have to explain. Did I tell you how grateful I am for what you've done?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I couldn't leave you sitting by the road.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You could have treated us like they did in Aspen. No. You wouldn't do a thing like that -- it isn't in you to be mean or cruel.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No man who brings up a kid like you've brought up Steve could ever be cruel to people.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I hope you get everything you want out of life --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You've earned it -- the horse ranch on the Toulomoe -- the girl in the spotted gingham.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: The who?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You should know. She's in your dream.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Ever since you've looked after Steve you've had the dream -- a ranch on the river -- good grass, good water, barn corral and house --- that part you've shared with Steve. The girl in gingham you plan sneakin' in when he isn't looking.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Go on. Tell me more about her.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: She wears this gingham dress -- cooks popovers -- makes jam in season -- makes her own soap from pig fat and wood ashes and has cheeks the color of red apples.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'll make the soap myself.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But the rest is right.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Will she be dark or fair?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Blonde as a new mop. And beautiful as the girl on a feed store calendar.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I hope you find her -- because, like I said, you've earned your dream. Goodnight.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Did you make it interesting?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I tried my best, but these things take time.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: And we're running out of that.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: There's still tomorrow morning.

Speaker: helen's voice
Dialogue: Those trunks look like ours.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: They are.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: How long do you think we'll have to stay here?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Until Pa gets around to driving us to Minden.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: We don't want to go there.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No we don't. But that's where we're going. From Minden we take a stage to Reno, then another one over to Auburn and another one to Placerville. Then it's a day's trip to Sonora.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Clay could save us an awful lot of time.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He certainly could. About a month.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: What are you waiting for? Do something.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You're not giving up?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: How many ways can a man say no.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Maybe I better start working on him.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You'd think he'd do it for Elaine's sake, at least...

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: If you can't bring him around, nobody can.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Go on. Have another try at him.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What's the use.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Please. Maybe he'll take a good look at you and stop thinking so much about his horses.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: A man has only so many no's in him.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Look at you, sitting up already.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Let me do this while you get some breakfast.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You're worn out.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Now don't argue. You've got two able- bodied girls to help you so take advantage of it. And don't let me catch you touching the dishes.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Well -- it's going to be good for all of us -- having a nice long rest here. After all -- Sonora will still be there next month. Maybe we can rehearse a new number -- try it out on your folks.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Helen -- why don't you and Mary go on with Clay?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He won't take us.  Don't you want us around?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Of course I do -- but it'd be better for you -- and the house is kind of small --

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: If you're worried about Mary and me talkin' too much, don't. No matter how many questions your old man asks. We know how to keep our mouths shut.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: It isn't that --

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Don't talk -- eat -- we want to get you well quick as we can so we can all get out of here.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: But I want to stay.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Drink this and stop being silly. Why would anyone want to live in this place. You might as well be dead and buried. Nothing to do but look at mountains. In a week you'd be talking to yourself.  Maybe that's what got you started in the first place.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I'm not going anywhere. I'm staying here where I belong.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Not if I know Mary. When she rides into Sonora, you'll be with her. And mighty glad to be there after this. I don't see how you stood it as long as you did.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Stop it -- stop it.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Darling -- now I've got you all upset.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Go away -- please.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: That's right -- you go back to sleep. Tomorrow when you feel better things will look a whole lot different. Don't you worry about anything -- Mary's going to talk things over with your folks --

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: She mustn't -- don't you let her --

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: There, there. Don't you upset yourself --

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: If she says anything to them I'll kill her.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: I don't want to leave you, ever.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Nothing. The poor child's worried about Mary --

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I won't let her say anything --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Well, I'm off --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Don't let them stay here, Mr. Phillips. They'll spoil everything.

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: Take them with you -- Mary's going to talk to dad -- she's going to keep talking and talking to me until maybe I won't want to stay here --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I can't --

Speaker: elaine
Dialogue: You've got to -- don't you understand -- they want me with them and they'll fix it so I have to go --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: No they won't.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: What comes after Z?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's the end of the line.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Then I know my alphabet.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: From A to Z. All you have to do now is figure out what they mean put together in words.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: And that's tough, isn't it?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Without someone to teach you, it's tough.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He knows his alphabet.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's fine.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'll bet I'd be reading in a week if --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Maybe Clay will take up where I left off.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I don't think it's fair --

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Leaving them here when we could just as well take them. We got plenty of room in the wagon. And -- and -- they cook and drive the mules. They don't bother anybody.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Finished, son?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: There's only two of them now.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'll round up the horses. Throw that junk in the wagon.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You were right -- a man has only so many no's in him. But he had me worried -- that last one sounded so final.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It's a lot tougher than I figured. Knowin' my letters is one thing. But makin' sense out of words is harder'n trackin' weasel after rain.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: -- and even if I do learn to read, what use'll it be? I'm goin' to live on a ranch!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: There's plenty of use for reading -- you'll see.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: U-n-i-c-o-r-n-... What in heck's that?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Unicorn -- a kind of animal --

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: What do they look like?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Hmmm... sort of like a horse -- with a horn in the center of its forehead.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Horses with horns! Huh! Do we have 'em in Nevada?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: How about California?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Would they be good to eat?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Kind of tough, I guess... But you're not liable to hunt them -- I don't think there's any alive now, anyways -- and I'm not sure but I don't think there ever were...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Then if they wasn't alive, how can they be an animal?...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: An' if you can't hunt 'em and even if you could they'd be tough, what's the use of knowin' how to spell them?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You don't read to fill your stomach... Poetry, for instance. All the poems in the world wouldn't fill you half as much as a bowl of eatmeal -- but they make you feel good.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I feel good anyways.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Don't go arguing with your teacher.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'm not, but there's some of it I don't see any sense to.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: There's a lot of things I don't see any sense to. But make up your mind. Learn to read or --  -- go back and watch the horses.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Well, Steve?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Now I know what a unicorn is, what do we do next?

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: We'll camp on up ahead away. That leg ain't good...

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: We're staying here until dark.  You put hobbles on the horses -- all of 'em. Get goin'.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Where you goin'? Over to the other side of the street?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Are we leaving?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: It's too light yet.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Better go on back and get some more sleep. You'll need it later on.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You're not going out to look for them?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: No, I'm not. All I want 'em to do is keep ahead of us -- a long way ahead. So I'm riding up the line aways to pick us out a new trail.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Nobody's gonna catch him sleeping. Don't worry about him.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I saw him saddling up and thought he was ready to leave.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You were worryin'.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Sometimes not knowin' how to read has its points. You can't read books so you look at people and figure 'em out.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And you've got me all figured out?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'll fix us somethin' to eat.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Like when you were standin' there looking after Clay. I knew right off what you were thinking. Because I've been watching you.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You were supposed to be reading words.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I was doin' both. Here.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Thanks, Steve.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Better not let Clay catch you waitin' on us.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Don't pay any attention to him. That's his way and I've found he's sure easy to get along with. I don't recollect him havin' hit me more'n a couple of times and I guess I had it comin'.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But you're his brother.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: He'll treat his wife just as good. Maybe better. Ever see him use a bull snake on the mules like other wranglers?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Yes sir, Clay's nice to be around.  He don't chew much and when he does he spits outside.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You make him sound wonderful... Go on. Tell Mary more about him.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: She was only teasin'.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Oh, sure.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Let me do that.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I like to do things for you. Didn't you know?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I know now.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't you trust me?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Not on this trail, I don't. I've been over it before. Anyway, you ought to be pretty sleepy. Why don't you climb in back.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I like to see where I'm going.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Did you ever care where you were goin' or where you'd been?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Maybe not! But I want to get there in one piece.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Why did you change your mind about bringing us along?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Why do you think?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I don't know. I thought I did. Now I'm not sure. I thought it had something to do with me.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Oh, it did. It had a great deal to do with you.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Just how do you mean that?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You know so much about me -- figure it out.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: So that's it --  You think I was making fun of your girl in gingham.

Speaker: mary's voice
Dialogue: I wasn't. And I wasn't making fun of you or your dream.

Speaker: mary's voice
Dialogue: Of course, maybe I was trying to get you to do something you didn't want to do.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You wouldn't do a thing like that, would you?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Yes. But -- that was the other night. Now -- I don't think I would.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's the West Walker. Take it easy now.

Speaker: fowler's voice
Dialogue: Hold it!

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: What are you doin' on this trail?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Followin' it. Any reason I shouldn't?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: My name's Fowler. I'm camped up a ways.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Clay Phillips of Aspen. Been havin' trouble?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Nope. But I don't want any.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Neither do we. That's why we took this trail instead of the main road, and drove all night.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: You're welcome to use my camp.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We might as well start a fire.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Go ahead.  Get in training for the pioneer life. I'm finding the nearest body of water and climbing into it.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Got a light?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Want the wagon unloaded, Clay?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Just the grub box and bed rolls.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I -- I think it'll be swell.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: When you get older you'll understand things better. Like women and men. Just because a man kisses a woman, doesn't always mean -- well, he can kiss her and not want to -- have her around all the time.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: We got a lot to do, you and I. Gettin' that ranch started and everything. We've been getting along fine, all these years. For a while I want to keep it the way it is.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Take that in and help her get breakfast, will you?

Speaker: fowler's voice
Dialogue: What are you doing down here?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: You got no business snoopin' around --

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Me snoopin'? I came down here to take a bath.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: That something I shouldn't see?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: No. But it's mine and I didn't want anyone foolin' with it.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Just a thing I was workin' on.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: The way you act, it must be something pretty secret.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Go on. Take your bath. I'll beat it.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You wouldn't have a smoke on you, would you?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: That sure smells good.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I like it.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Up here in the hills, a man gets a hankering to smell powder.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Then why stay in the hills.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: That why?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: I guess you can keep a secret. That's a gold rocker. I'm doin' a little placer mining in a place nobody ever thought to look for gold before.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Look at her -- see her shine. One week's work.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Roll me a cigarette, Clay.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Why didn't you wake me?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You should have. I don't like leaving things unfinished.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Maybe it's better that way.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You don't mean that Clay.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Tell me, darling.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What does a man usually tell a girl?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Tell me -- please --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: All right you don't love me. So let it go at that.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What did you expect? Speeches I don't mean?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I don't expect anything. A minute ago I hadn't cuite waked up.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm awake now. Go on. Say what you want to say. I'll listen.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: If it's pretty speeches you want, you won't be hearing them. Even when I mean 'em, they don't come easy.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Save 'em for the girl in gingham. Just tell me I'm not good enough for you. Go on. Say a woman like me can't change.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: All right -- it's said!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Then let's get started. The sooner I get to Sonora, the better I'll like it.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You're sure there's more where this came from?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Plenty more.  And somewhere up there's the lode, the rock rotten with it.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Pretty, isn't it? And all you have to do is shovel sand into a thing and the river does the work.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Give it back to him. We're leavin'.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Maybe you are. I'm not.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm stayin' here with Jed.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: I figure we'll get along just fine.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Well cheer, why don't you? No more responsibilities, Mary. Marcia -- Elaine -- me -- all taken care of. Down there feeding horses and raising kids, you won't have a thing to worry about.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm not raising horses or kids for anybody. I'm opening the slickest gambling house in California with a crystal chandelier, the biggest you ever saw --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: -- Gaslights and a dance floor and a big bar. Cash registers with bells and a couple of boys with armbands just to keep 'em ringing. What do you think of that?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Sounds fine. Only that isn't how it's going to be.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm sure of this. But not of you.  You won't open any joint. I've been watching you change. You're mad now and you think you can change back. But you can't. You'll end up making beds in a boarding house.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's it then.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: That's it. She's staying with me -- for keeps.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: If there were more men like you, there wouldn't be so many of us.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's nice to meet a man who doesn't want to own a woman from the day she was born. I never had the luck. The only kind I've run into were tramps or dirty-minded hypocrites.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Want to know why I changed my mind about bringing you? Because I talked to Elaine -- because I was afraid to leave you with decent people, that's why. And you'll open your joint all right. You wouldn't fit anywhere else.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Let's round up the horses.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Come on -- we don't want to keep the people in Sonora waiting.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Mary, Honey. I talked too much, like always -- he thinks you told Elaine the things I told her.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I don't care what he thinks.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Clay -- look!

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Mary --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No, I'm not all right. I'm soaked and I hit myself against that rock.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I suppose that's my fault.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: All my clothes --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That's right -- worry about your clothes --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What about my wagon. Of all the crazy fool things to do. You lose a man's wagon because you're stupid and then yell about your clothes.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: For the wagon.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Go on, take it. Then you can't spend the rest of the trip expecting to get paid.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: There won't be any rest of the trip. Over the hill is a stage road and when we hit it you get dumped into the first stage that comes along. So keep your money. You'll need it for the fare. I'm fed up with you. I was fed up with you before we started.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Don't just stand there. Go on back and get the packs on the horses. We've lost all the time we're going to because of a woman.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Come on. Didn't you hear me?

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: We got company. Female company.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Yeah, we sure have.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You can put this out of the way, Jed. It's empty.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: I saw your fire and dropped by to say hello.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Well, say it.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: What's the matter -- restless?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Yes, people make me restless.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Even women?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: There aren't any women here.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: I suppose that's your wagon in the river.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Some people who went by this way lost it.  Two men and some women. They packed their stuff on horses and went on.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: And you're all alone.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Suppose I take a look.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: Looking for something?

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Hold it, Mac.

Speaker: lednov's voice
Dialogue: Get up.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Come on. Where'd the women go?

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: When I ask questions, I like to hear answers.

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: They went on like I told you.

Speaker: lednov's voice
Dialogue: How long ago?

Speaker: fowler
Dialogue: Five, six hours.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Sit down.  All right, Peters, come on over here.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: So you were all alone.

Speaker: peters
Dialogue: You keep your hands off.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Let him alone!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Kick a guy, would you! You scum! You won't do any kickin' when they come back.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You dirty murderers... killin' people when they're sleepin'...

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: How do you know who we are?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Everybody knows --

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Who brought you here?

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: You said somebody was comin' back -- who's comin' back?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Stop it --

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Clay Phillips.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Where is he?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Up the trail.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: How far up the trail?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I don't know -- I don't know.

Speaker: peters
Dialogue: You didn't have to do that.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Why not? She might have got to Clay Phillips before I did.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: For the last ten miles I've been trying to figure out how to sleep sitting up. I'm getting to the point where I don't think there's any place named Sonora.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It's a long ways yet.  I figure we ought to camp. She's tired.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: So am I and so are the horses.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Take the packs off. And run the horses into the corral.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I said take the packs off.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I figure we'll make better time, letting the horses rest for a spell.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: So grab yourself some sleep while you have the chance.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: If you want to go on, I can make it all right.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Like I said, I was thinkin' of the horses.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You stretch out. I'll fix something to eat.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Thanks, Steve.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: If you want 'em to find us, why don't you go up on the hill and wave your shirt or fire your rifle.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I didn't stop to think, Clay.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You better start.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Maybe you and me better split up when we hit Sonora.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: All right, I hurt your feelings. But you know better than to go lightin' fires.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: That ain't why. I just figure it's about time to start runnin' my own life.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Maybe you're not hungry, but I am.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Come on. We got a couple hours to eat and get some sleep.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: I'll eat when I'm good and ready.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Kind of feeling your oats this morning. I haven't laid a hand on you for quite a while, but that doesn't mean you're too old.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: What makes you think you're so almighty? Telling people what to do and how to act when you don't even know how yourself.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You ain't even man enough to own up when you're wrong.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Go on, hit me.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Sit down and eat. Till I say the word, you're doing what you're told.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You oughta say you're sorry -- that's what you oughta do.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You keep your nose out of my life, young fella.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Maybe I haven't lived as long as you have, but I know a sight more about people and I wouldn't talk to a mule like you talked to her and, if I did, I'd say how sorry I was. I'd be man enough to do that.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I said keep your nose out of my life. No kid is going to tell me how to run it.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You think you're so slmighty -- smart -- Who are you to sit up there and say nobody's good enough for you, like you said yesterday -- just because a man kisses a woman --

Speaker: steve's voice
Dialogue: -- doesn't mean he wants to marry her.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Well, if you didn't mean it, why did you kiss her?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Shut up and eat.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Stop it -- both of you.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I won't have you fighting over me.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You don't know what it is to be sorry.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Steve --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Mind sortin' out my things -- I'm leaving.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Maybe it isn't going to Sonora, but it's going somewhere, which is all right with me.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: It's going to Sonora.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Fine -- maybe I'll see you there sometime.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Because as you said, that's where I belong.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I said a lot of things -- some of 'em --

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Some of 'em you didn't mean but most of 'em you did. I don't blame you because I understand your way of thinking and why you think that way. You want your women on pedestals. But they have to be born on 'em -- they can fall off but they can't climb back up.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I can't help how I think. You're trained a certain way when you're a kid and you can't change.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: If you're gonna catch this stage, come on.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I can't change either. Not unless somebody wants me enough to give me a hand.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Hurry up.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm fool enough to believe that one of these days somebody will. Somebody who wants me as I am will maybe walk into the place where I'm working and take me out of there.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Maybe they will.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Mind giving a lady a lift into town?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Climb right in.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Will you be seeing the sheriff?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Depot's right next to his office.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Goodbye, ma'am.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Goodbye, Steve. Don't fight with him any more.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's not his fault, just you remember that. It's mine. Don't ask me why because you couldn't understand now. Some day you will.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Goodbye. Thanks for the lift.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Goodbye, Mary.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: By the way, if you ever go past the Wyatt ranch, have another talk with Elaine.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: You know what she asked me?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I don't care what she asked you.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: She told me not to fight with you anymore. She said it wasn't your fault, but -- I figure different...

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It is so your fault and... and I guess maybe when we hit the ranch... you andme better...

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You want to split up? --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: -- Why wait? Go on, saddle up now and beat it.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Half of them are mine.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You'll get your share. Go on. I don't want you around.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: There you are.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: What did you come back for?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Like I told you, half those horses are mine. I'm makin' sure they get to the ranch safe. So let's quit arguing and do whatever you figure on doin'.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Is that the only reason you came back?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Sure. What other reason would there be?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I just wondered. Let's go.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Go on down and have a look.

Speaker: peters
Dialogue: And get my head blown off! Not me.

Speaker: mccall
Dialogue: Call it.

Speaker: peters
Dialogue: Heads.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: And you! Get going.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Stick here.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Come on out, Phillips.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Those horses down there -- they don't amount to much to me. Look at the one with the bell.

Speaker: lednov
Dialogue: Next time I won't miss.

Speaker: lednov's voice
Dialogue: Watch the one with the white face.

Speaker: clay's voice
Dialogue: I'm here Lednov.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Come on out.

Speaker: lednov's voice
Dialogue: Come and get me.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Kind of sore.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: You'll live.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Guess maybe I'm old enough to hold my own in a fight, huh?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Yeah -- but don't make a habit of it.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: So -- maybe I'm old enough to tell you how to run your life?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: I guess so -- but don't make a habit of it.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Well, then, I know it takes three -- four weeks for you to come round to admit when you're wrong... But by that time she's liable to be in China...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Hold her steady. I'm not hurting him.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Maybe you're not, but I'll sure be glad when you stop pokin' me.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Is it very bad?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Course not. A scratch.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: What are you doin' here?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Holding the lamp.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Then hold it a little lower.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Thanks for taking over.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Thanks for loading me on the stage. I know now why you did it.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Like I said, women get in the way sometimes.

Speaker: steve's voice
Dialogue: He tried to get rid of me, too, Miss Wells.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Keep still, will you.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Put him over there on the cot. Goodnight... He'll be all right.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Goodnight.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Goodnight, Miss Wells.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: If you need me, I'll be --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Where you going?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: To the other side of the street.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Mary.

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: That job you were talkin' about, did you get it yet?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Because... well, you said you wanted a man to think enough of you to walk in the place you were working and take you out of there... tonight I was sort of tied up with Steve... but tomorrow I figured on doing just that.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I haven't got the job yet.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: But if you want to wait until tomorrow --

Speaker: clay
Dialogue: Is there any place in town a man could buy some gingham?
